awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Disentangling causes and consequences of religious conversion
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Why do people adopt a novel set of religious beliefs and practices, especially if it is a minority one and doing so is potentially costly? This doctoral dissertation research project explores the conditions that make it more likely for someone to convert to a new religion and measures the consequences of conversions for cooperation across religious and ethnic boundaries. Results can help us understand the underlying drivers of recent large-scale shifts in religious affiliation, and their potential consequences for inter-group cooperation and market integration. Additionally, this project will provide research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, offer methods training to underprivileged academic communities, and disseminate results to both English and Spanish-speaking audiences.
 
By using mixed methods in an ethnographic context experiencing high rates of conversion from Catholicism to various forms of Protestantism, this study can help adjudicate between the relative contributions of material motivations, assortment along shared values, and social learning heuristics in driving conversion decisions. This will include conducting retrospective semi-structured interviews, vignette experiments, economic games, and analysis of longitudinal census data. Economic approaches to conversion highlight the economic outcomes that often follow shifts in religious affiliation, suggesting that material motivations drive conversions. However, conversions are not always followed by improved economic outcomes, and even when they are, they may not be driven by material concerns. This project could shed light on the mechanisms involved in conversion processes by introducing a cultural evolutionary approach which focuses on the transmission pathways through which these ideas spread, and their interaction with human motivations and cultural norms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral dissertation research project explored the causes and consequences of religious conversions in Latin America. It focused on the case study of Tenejapa, an agricultural Mayan town in the southernmost state of Chiapas, Mexico. This region has shown surprisingly high levels of religious conversion to Protestantism since the second half of the 20th century, in what has otherwise remained a largely Catholic country (Mexico is the 2nd most Catholic country in the continent). Tenejapa currently has a population of 48 thousand people. Over half of those today practice a Protestant faith (e.g., Presbyterianism, Pentecostalism, Adventism). Yet in 1950, only 18 people were registered as Protestants by the Mexican Population Census.

This research project tries to identify the mechanisms through which these novel religious beliefs and behaviors spread so effectively. It does so by asking not only why someone exposed to Protestantism chooses to convert, but also by inversely investigating why some choose not to convert, despite being exposed. 71 of the 174 participants interviewed between October 2022 and December 2023 were people that remained in the religious faith they were born in. This will allow me to statistically identify the way in which these two groups of individuals were systematically different prior to being exposed to these new religious ideas: their past social network, socioeconomic conditions, educational levels, exposure to other cultural groups, and market integration.

This research project also compares the outcomes of these conversion events by not only comparing how these two groups are different today (relative to their exposure to Protestantism), but by comparing Protestants that did convert and Protestants who were born into their faith. This will allow me to explore whether any benefits that result from joining these new religious groups are long-lasting. Given Chiapas is the poorest and least educated state in Mexico, religious conversion may be a strategy through which these disenfranchised populations culturally adapt to a modernizing landscape. Alternatively, religious conversion may be less associated with material gains, and more associated with preferential assortment with individuals that share non-traditional norms and moral values.

Descriptive preliminary results have been returned to the different churches that collaborated on this project. Statistical analysis of the data collected is ongoing, and should be submitted for publication to peer-reviewed scientific journals sometime through 2025 and 2026.
